levels.title: What Are Smart Devices?
cards: Smart devices — or IoT devices — are everyday electronics that connect to the internet.
Examples include smart thermostats, lights, doorbells, security cameras, fridges, or even coffee machines.
They usually have sensors and software that allow them to collect data and interact with other devices or users.
Most are controlled through a mobile app or voice assistant like Alexa or Google Assistant.
Because they’re so integrated into our lives, they’ve become a juicy target for hackers.

levels.title: How Smart Homes Can Be Attacked
cards: Smart homes rely on many connected devices that communicate with each other and your phone.
Hackers can look for weak points, like devices with default usernames or passwords.
Outdated software (called firmware) can have bugs that let attackers take control.
Once inside your network, an attacker can spy, unlock smart doors, or control other devices.
Most attacks happen because people forget to update devices or leave them unprotected.

levels.title: Real-World Smart Home Hacks
cards: In 2016, the Mirai botnet took over thousands of smart cameras and caused massive internet outages.
Some smart baby monitors were accessed by strangers who spoke through them — terrifying, right?
These attacks happened because devices were left with default passwords or weren’t updated.
Smart TVs, fridges, even lightbulbs have been used as part of hacking tools.
It’s not science fiction — it’s happening right now, and it’s preventable.
